title: 109_hr3779
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The National Women's Rights History Project Act of 2005 recognizes the women's rights movement as a significant protest tradition in U.S. history. It highlights the Seneca Falls Convention in 1848 and the formation of the National American Women Suffrage Association (NAWSA) under Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony. The National American Women Suffrage Association (NAWSA) played a key role in securing the passage of the 19th amendment, granting women the right to vote. Susan B. Anthony, a prominent figure in the women's rights movement, fought for women's suffrage and other rights such as property ownership and custody of children. The women's movement also influenced policies on economic and social welfare in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Women's Rights National Historical Park is amended to include the Votes for Women History Trail Route as a new feature. The Women's Rights National Historical Park in Seneca Falls and Waterloo, New York, has the opportunity to partner with related properties in the corridor between Syracuse and Rochester, including the Susan B. Anthony House, to tell the story of the 72-year fight for women's suffrage. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to establish a vehicular tour route called the 'Votes for Women History Trail Route' linking properties in New York associated with the struggle for women's suffrage, to be administered by the National Park Service. The Votes for Women History Trail Route will be administered by the National Park Service through the Women's Rights National Historical Park. The Secretary will produce educational materials, coordinate management with other agencies, create an official symbol for the trail, and issue guidelines for its use. The Secretary may designate official stops on the Votes for Women History Trail Route at properties related to women's suffrage, including units of Women's Rights National Historical Park and other relevant governmental and nongovernmental facilities. The Secretary is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements and provide financial assistance for the Votes for Women History Trail Route, ensuring coordination between Federal and non-Federal properties. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal years 2006-2010. The Secretary can enter agreements for the Votes for Women History Trail Route, ensuring coordination between Federal and non-Federal properties. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal years 2006-2010, with cooperating entities under agreements or memorandums. SEC. 3. NATIONAL WOMEN'S RIGHTS HISTORY PROJECT NATIONAL REGISTRY. The Secretary of the Interior can provide grants to State historic preservation offices for up to 5 years to survey, evaluate, and nominate women's rights history properties to the National Register of Historic Places. Priority is given to properties associated with various aspects of the women's rights movement. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these grants. Authorization of appropriations is provided to the Secretary of the Interior for fiscal years 2006 through 2010 to carry out grants for women's rights history properties. The National Women's Rights History Project Partnerships Network is established. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to provide grants and technical assistance for the development of a network focused on national women's rights history, including historic preservation. The network will be managed by a nongovernmental entity in partnership with the National Park Service and State historic preservation offices. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to receive necessary funds for fiscal years 2006 to 2010 to implement grants and technical assistance for a network focusing on national women's rights history and historic preservation.
